text: in the UK and I think possibly other
parts of Europe um TVs of course were
analog then um there was no digital TV
for another 20 odd years um but what the
but the the analog signal effectively
only used about half of the transmit
time for about half of the time it was
in fly back um horizontally or
vertically um and this time was allowed
uh for Fairly Antiquated analog circuits
to keep up and this meant that there
were there were lines that were not used
for transmitting a picture and in the UK
and Europe um some fairly simple digital
information was overlaid on those lines
um in the system um that became known as
as cax or teletext I think there were
there were different trade names
depending on which broadcaster you were
referring to these used a particularly
efficient mode of display where with a
kilobyte of ram you could basically fill
a TV screen with multicolored text and
fairly blocky graphics and the BBC was
Keen that the BBC micro um supported
that display standard so this was added
to the basic proton architecture um it's
quite tricky to add because the proton
um used display modes that were divided
down from 16 MHz bit rates teletex
display required it 6 mahz okay and
uh it's fairly easy to spot the that 6
MHz isn't easily arrived at by dividing
160 MHz um it doesn't go no so I I I
came up with a what I think was a really
rather a neat fudge um it was done
digitally it didn't use a phas lock loop
or anything that complicated um it
basically used edges um in the 16 MHz
signal that were reasonably close and
then rather crude RC delays to just
shift them a little bit in the right
direction to produce something that was
fairly close to a real 6 MHz signal so
